column1: #Text=cooking is the chief cause of this error in judgment._ No doubt a well
#Text= broiled steak is more appetizing and delicate in flavor than some of
#Text= the cheaper cuts, but in proportion to the cost is not equal in
#Text= nutritive value; careful cooking and judicious flavoring render the
#Text= cheaper pieces of beef equally palatable.
#Text= necessary to maintain life has been clearly demonstrated by the
#Text= traditional diet of the Scotch people with their oatmeal and herring;
#Text= the Irish, potatoes and buttermilk; New England, codfish and potatoes,
#Text= and pork and beans; the Chinese, rice, etc.
#Text= is not recommended, for reasons given in a previous chapter, and in
#Text= the countries where a special diet prevails owing to the climate,
#Text= nature of soil and markets, the results have not warranted us in
#Text= believing that it is as good as a mixed diet.
#Text= brief outline of the food question we have learned (1) that a
#Text= knowledge of the requirements of the body are absolutely necessary in
#Text= regulating a proper diet; (2) to furnish the food principles in a
#Text= cheap rather than a dear form; (3) to understand the art of cookery so
#Text= as to secure the full nutritive value and at the same time stimulate
#Text= the appetite; (4) the value of economy in regard to food principles.
#Text=When the housekeeper has acquired this knowledge she will have covered
#Text= the kinds and amount of nutritive substances our bodies need and our
#Text= food materials contain, then and not till then shall we be able to
#Text= adjust our diet to the demands of health and purse."
#Text=It is sometimes asked, why do we cook our food?
#Text= will occur during this course of instruction for a comparison of the
#Text= customs and diet of the various countries, and the advance of
#Text= civilization in this direction, we will confine ourselves to the
#Text= definition of the term as it concerns ourselves.
#Text=Atkinson says, that "Cooking is the right application of heat for
#Text=As much of our food requires cooking, how we shall cook it so as to
#Text= render it more palatable, more digestible, and with the greatest
#Text= economy of time, fuel and money, is an object deserving the most
#Text=The art of cooking lies in the power to develop
#Text= certain flavors which are agreeable to the palate, or in other words,
#Text= which "make the mouth water," without interfering with the nutritive
#Text= qualities of the food prepared, to understand by what method certain
#Text= foods may be rendered more digestible, and to provide variety.
#Text=Monotony of diet and of flavor lessens the appetite and fails to
#Text=The chemical changes, produced by cooking food properly, aid
#Text= digestion, beside destroying any germs which may be contained in the
#Text= digestibility of starch depends almost entirely upon the manner in
#Text= which it is cooked, especially the cereal class.
#Text= sure to follow the use of improperly cooked grains or starches.
#Text=The following are the usual methods observed in cooking, viz.: (1)
#Text= Broiling is cooking directly over the hot coals.
#Text= coagulated albumen is formed upon the outer surface.
#Text= prevents the evaporation of the juices, which with the extractive
#Text= materials are retained and improve the flavor.
#Text= has a decided advantage, in both flavor and nutritive value, over that
#Text= which has been boiled or stewed.
#Text= kinds of meat that are suitable for broiling.
#Text=The boiling point of fat is far above
#Text=Fat should not be heated above 400° F., as it will then
#Text= turn dark and emit a disagreeable odor.
#Text= for frying is to immerse the food completely in a bath of hot fat.
#Text=Braising is cooking meat in a covered vessel surrounded by a solution
#Text=of vegetable and animal juices in a strong but not boiling
#Text=Tough meat may be rendered very palatable and nutritious
#Text=The cover of the pan or kettle must fit
#Text=The flavor is improved by browning the meat in either hot
#Text= fat or in a very hot oven before braising.
#Text=Meat properly cooked in an oven is
#Text= considered by many authorities as quite equal in delicacy of flavor to
#Text= that roasted before a fire, and is equally digestible.
#Text=Steaming is cooking food over condensed steam, and is an excellent
#Text= method for preparing food which requires long, slow cooking.
#Text= cereals, and other glutinous mixtures are often cooked in this way.
#Text= is an economical method, and has the advantage of developing flavor
#Text=Well smoked bacon cut thin and properly cooked is a
#Text= digestible form of fatty food, especially for tubercular patients.
#Text=Salting is one of the oldest methods of preserving food.
#Text= of a little saltpetre helps to preserve the color of the meat.
#Text= is frequently used to temporarily preserve meat and other substances.
#Text=Corned beef is a popular form of salt preservation.
#Text=They should always be placed in cold water
#Text= and heated gradually in order to extract the salt.
#Text= digestible and not quite so nutritious as fresh meats.
#Text=Food may be kept in a frozen condition almost indefinitely, but will
#Text= decompose very quickly when thawed, hence the necessity for cooking
#Text=Frozen meat loses 10 per cent. of its nutritive value in
#Text=This process does not involve actual freezing, but implies
#Text= preservation in chambers at a temperature maintained a few degrees
#Text=This method does not affect the flavor or
#Text= nutritive value of food so much as freezing.
#Text=Sealing is accomplished not only in the process of canning but by
#Text= covering with substances which are impermeable.
#Text= preserved for considerable time by immersing in hot fat in which it
#Text= was allowed to remain after cooling.
#Text=Chemicals are sometimes used in the preservation of food, but the
#Text=valuable being the albuminoids: the gelatinoid of meat is easily
#Text= changed into gelatin by the action of hot water.
#Text= with the albuminoids and extractives has considerable nutritive value.
#Text=Extractives are meat bases, or rather meat which has been dissolved by
#Text= water, such as soup stock and beef tea.
#Text= to soften and loosen the tissue, which renders it more easily
#Text=Another object is to sterilize or kill any germs which may
#Text= exist and to make it more palatable.

#Text=Cooking affects the digestibility of meat, which is evident from the

#Text= It may be well to add here that animal food is more digestible when
#Text= cooked between 160° and 180° F. than at a higher temperature.
#Text= In boiling meat two principles must be considered, the softening of
#Text= the fibre and preserving of the juices.
#Text=If the meat alone is to be

#Text= so as to harden the albumen and prevent the escape of the juices.

#Text=The use of alcohol is wholly unnecessary for the health of the human
#Text=Condiments and spices are used as food adjuncts; they supply little
#Text= nourishment, the effect being mainly stimulating, and are very
#Text=They add flavor to food and relieve
#Text=The use of such condiments as pepper, curry,

#Text=the only necessary condiment, for reasons given in the chapter on
#Text=The blending of flavors so as to make food more

#Text=Some flavors, such as lemon juice, vinegar, etc., increase the solvent

#Text=The knowledge of food values and their relation to the body will be of
#Text= little use for practical purposes unless combined with the knowledge
#Text= of how the various foods should be prepared, either by cooking or in
#Text= whatever form circumstances and the material may require.
#Text= requisite for cooking purposes is heat; this necessitates the use of
#Text=The fuels chiefly used for household purposes are wood, coal,
#Text=Soft woods, such as pine or birch, are best for
#Text= kindling and for a quick fire.
#Text=Hard woods, oak, ash, etc., burn more
#Text= slowly, retain the heat longer, and are better adapted for cooking
#Text= gives a steady heat, and burns for a longer time without attention
#Text=Stoves for burning oil and gas have become popular, and are
#Text= very convenient and satisfactory for cooking purposes.
#Text=Oil is considered to be the cheapest fuel.
#Text=Gas is a very satisfactory fuel for cooking purposes, but can only be
